column2: Does your landlord or home insurance place any breed or weight restrictions on the animals you are allowed to have?
column4: Do you have screens in your windows?
column5: Are all the members of your household in agreement about adopting a dog?
column6: Does anyone in the household have pet allergies?
column7: Do you live in public housing (NYCHA, projects, section 8)?
column8: Are you at least 21 years of age and head of household? If not, you will not be approved to adopt with IOHR.
column9: Why do you want to adopt a dog?
column10: What energy level would work with your lifestyle?
column11: Are your pets up to date on their vaccinations and monthly preventatives (flea/tick and heartworm)?
column12: Where have your current and previous animals come from? Please list the adoption agency, shelter, or breeder if applicable.
column13: Are your current cats/dogs spayed or neutered and have your past cats/dogs been spayed or neutered?
column14: Have you ever bred an animal
column15: Please provide the name and phone number for your most recent or current veterinarian (even if you don't have the animals anymore). What name are the records listed under? Please note that some vets require your permission to release information to us; please call your vet now and give them permission as this will help expedite the application process!
column16: On a regular day, how many hours will the dog be left alone?
column17: Where will the dog be kept?
column18: Do you have a contingency plan to pay for unexpected emergency vet bills?
column19: How soon do you want to adopt a pup?
column20: Have you ever had to give up a pet? If so, why and where did the pet go?
column21: Have you been involved in domestic disturbances in which the police were called in your current living situation?
column22: If you are adopting with a partner, are you in agreement that the dog will go with one of you should you separate, and not be surrendered back to us or a shelter?
column23: Are you willing to work through unexpected hardships with your pet and hire a trainer if need be? i.e. housetraining, separation anxiety, fear, socialization, acclimation to other animals, etc

column9: I grew up around dogs and have always loved being around animals of all shapes and sizes. Since being in NYC for almost a decade, I have lived with a few roommates who have had dogs and have loved every minute, but I've been counting down the days until the time when I'm ready to adopt a dog of my own. I'm a person who plans, so I'm finally at the point in my life where I am 100% ready and prepared to take on all the responsibilities of owning a pet (I know it is definitely not easy). As I stated before, I recently moved into a large one bedroom that is pet-friendly solely for the purpose of adopting a dog--and there is a park a few blocks away! I also have a lot of friends who now have dogs as well, so I feel like I have a community of fellow dog-owners and lovers around me at all times to provide support to me and my pet. All that being said, I know that I could not just financially take care of a dog, but I would give it SO much love and ensure that she/he is always safe and happy.

column17: He/she will be kept either in a crate or a pen of some sort so that I know he/she is safe and can not potentially cause any harm to himself. Based on our shared comfort level, I will then slowly allow him to access a little more space during short periods of alone time to see how he behaves. I will have cameras set up so that I'm able to monitor his actions no matter what at all times of day. My goal is to be able to allow him to have free reign of the apartment and not have to be crated ever.

Adopting a pup is very important to us, so when we stumbled upon the Newfiepoo pups we instantly fell in love. Cristhian and I are both very active and would love a pup to take on runs and on hikes with us. My family lives 45 minutes out of the city in Nyack, we visit frequently and would take our pup with us to enjoy some time out of the city. After just a few short months, it became evident that she had a lot of energy, and would most likely prefer another dog in the house with whom she could play.  She gets excited for trips to grandmom’s, where she has play dates with her two Bassett Hound cousins. column9: I love animals, particularly dogs. I've had two dogs - both rescues since living in NYC over the last 20 years.  My first dog, Marie was adopted via Eve's Sanctuary Animal Rescue in 2009.  Though already a senior, she lived until 2017.  I loved her and still do immensely.  She succumbed to natural causes (a series of strokes, my vet believes + liver disease/failure) and we had her put to sleep in October 2017.  I adopted another chihuahua in July 2018 from Beastly Pet Rescue here in NYC.  He lived only a few months.  He was a senior too and had some eye issues, but lived really happily for a few months until early Dec and he failed very quickly one evening.  We took him to Blue Pearl emergency in Hells Kitchen and they concluded that he was in congestive heart failure and would not live through the night.  We decided immediately to put him to sleep so he would not suffer.  He was having trouble breathing and was panicked.  It was very hard but I know we gave him a beautiful ending to a rather unsatisfying life.  He had a warm bed (mine lol), good food and a lot of attention. In addition to cashmere sweaters -ha!  I feel it's a service to adopt dogs, particularly ones that are not puppies.  I am looking for a chihuahua - small - preferably below 5-6 lbs.  as I would like to take the dog with me to work, and while i'm outdoors in NYC.  I did this with my first dog Marie quite often - I took her around in a cross body sling, secured in and close to me.   Age does not matter too much but I very much prefer to adopt a dog that is not a puppy or too old (I just went though that).  Middle aged is great.  Or a bit older : )

column20: Yes, we adopted a young pit mix (about 1 year old) from Sean Casey about 8 years ago. She turned out to be extremely excitable, would grab my children's arms and try to wrestle. We could not get her to calm down when she got into her frenzies. A trainer we hired advised that she would have a very hard time learning to chill out in our very active home with very active young boys, and she recommended that the dog go to a home without children, or with older children . We very reluctantly returned her to Sean Casey. (She was adopted by a young couple with no children a week later.) My boys are a lot older now, and there's not the same amount of high-energy activity in the house now. Plus we'd engage in positive-reinforcement training from the start.  Also, since that failed adoption, we've fostered a bunch of dogs (for Badass Brooklyn Animal Rescue) so we are fairly experienced with dogs at this point.

column9: I grew up with active dogs - a lab, a Dalmatian, a hound, and a border collie. I have always loved dogs and have longed to have one as an adult. Now, as a 32-year old adult, I am familiar with and prepared to give the love, care and routine that a dog needs. My partner, Carlos, and I are active and love to take walks, go for runs, take weekend trips outside the city, or stand outside the dog park - wishing we had our own pup to play with. I have worked in elementary special education for 11 years, and because work required me to be away for 8+ hours daily, I could not have a dog in NYC. However, I stopped working in schools to start a new role in August that affords me a flexible schedule and the ability to work from home at least 3 days per week. Now, I teach adult teachers, and when I must go to campus, it's for no more than 6 hours 2x weekly (between 3pm-9pm); Carlos arrives home around 7pm each night, so a dog would not be left alone for more than 4 hours a couple times weekly. January is the perfect time for us to adopt, bond with, and train a new pup because my graduate students will be on winter break until the end of the month. In other words, I can be home with the new dog 7 days/week until February!

column17: The dog would be with us most of the time.  My husband works as a firefighter so his schedule allows him to be home a lot.    On days that we are both at work (I works M-F, 9-5+), our current dog has been going to doggy daycare with our dog sitters, but we've also just arranged for them to come by several times throughout the day to walk/play and feed Jackson.  The services are provided by a husband and wife team and they are very flexible about meeting the needs of their clients and their pets (they live about 10 mins from us).  We can make whatever arrangements are needed for any dog that joins our family.  At night, our current dog is crated in our bedroom.  We also have a pen on the main floor that has a bed, water and a cushioned area for times where we need to run out or cannot properly supervise him.  We would make whatever additional arrangements would be needed for a second dog, but it's hard to say what that would be without meeting him/her first.  We have a great basement area that allows our dog to play inside on cold/rainy days.

column9: We are diehard dog people. We adopted a pit / Staffordshire terrier mix over 2 years ago. She became our best friend and love of our lives. We had a great time with her with many adventures and many cuddles. Unfortunately, in the last 4 months of her life, she became effected by a rare brain disease called Meningoencyphalitis. It started off very minor and the vets thought it was an ear infection, it progressed and progressed to the point where she couldn't stand up. We went through uncountable medications and vet / animal hospital visits. We had a specialist who guided us through steroid therapy, which proved unsuccessful, and then chemotherapy, which also did not work. In her last week, Dora could not move at all. In her last two days, she wouldn't eat or drink water. We had to put her down. It was the hardest thing we ever had to do. Now we are ready to bring a new puppy into our home and share a long life with them.

column6: Last year to our surprise when Chiara had a general allergy panel done, it did show an indicator to a mild dog sensitivity. We were surprised because she has been around dogs a lot, both dogsitting for friends and family in our home as well as being in many dog homes for extended time and she has been ok. When this came up last year, we discussed with the allergist our intention to adopt a dog this year and given context the doctor approved, but suggested we seek a "hypoallergenic" breed. We know this does not mean the dog would truly be hypoallergenic as no dog truly is, but we as a result we are narrowing our search to breeds that are generally thought of this way (low shed hair, etc.)

column9: Our whole family loves dogs. Both my husband and I had dogs growing up. We both have long wanted a dog as adults, but through our 20's and early 30's living in NYC in small apartments with roommates, inconsistent schedules, etc. neither of us felt it was the right time to be a good dog parent. Then when we had kids of our own, we decided to wait until they were a bit older. We finally really feel like we are in a great place to provide a dog with a loving, comfortable and stable forever home. We now live in a single family home we own with a great and fully fenced yard, our kids are in a phase where they are great, respectful and gentle to dogs. We can't wait to welcome a dog to our family :)NOTE: below I listed active, but really mellow or active is good.

column9: Based on our experience purchasing a dog from a pet store, we realized that we had missed out on the feeling of giving a dog in need a better home, and were naive to the fact that many breeders are using unhealthy practices when breeding dogs for profit. We no longer wanted to support this method and decided that if and when we desired another dog we would do so through a rescue that we knew had a good reputation. We have been longing for a larger breed for a few years now as my husband and I's first dog was a German Shepard/Pitbull mix and we missed that bond. We decided that once our children had gotten older, we would begin our search for another dog because we felt our children would be ready for the responsibility and have had experience with other dog breeds. My family and I feel we are finally ready to receive the love and the connection that larger breeds give differently, and I personally miss the slobber kisses !

column20: In January 2017 I had to move to New York City for a new job. I temporarily left my cat with close friend who loves cats, owns a cat of her own, and lives in a big house with a yard in a nice neighborhood where the cat could safely roam outside. My intent was to find an apartment in New York that allowed tenants to have cats. Then I would return to California to retrieve my cat. However, when I returned to California, I saw how happy the cat was in his new home with my friend, and how much he loved running around outside and playing with her other cat. I felt that it wouldn't be fair to the cat to force him to be cooped up in an NYC apartment with no outdoor access, being deprived of the ability to explore and play in an outdoor habitat. So I left the cat with her, and I periodically check up on him and visit him.  He is doing very well.  I would now like a dog because I am able to provide a dog with an active, positive, happy life. My active lifestyle is compatible with that of a dog. Unlike a cat, I can take the dog running with me and play with him/her outside in the park.

column20: In January 2017 I had to move to New York City for a new job. I temporarily left my cat with close friend who loves cats, owns a cat of her own, and lives in a big house with a yard in a nice neighborhood where the cat could safely roam outside. My intent was to find an apartment in New York that allowed tenants to have cats. Then I would return to California to retrieve my cat. However, when I returned to California, I saw how happy the cat was in his new home with my friend, and how much he loved running around outside and playing with her other cat. I felt that it wouldn't be fair to the cat to force him to be cooped up in an NYC apartment with no outdoor access, being deprived of the ability to explore and play in an outdoor habitat. So I left the cat with her, and I periodically check up on him and visit him.  He is doing very well.  I would now like a dog because I am able to provide a dog with an active, positive, happy life. My active lifestyle is compatible with that of a dog. Unlike a cat, I can take the dog running with me and play with him/her outside in the park.

Niko was my friend and confidant for 11 years before cancer took him from me in February of 2016, despite my, and Tufts Foster Medical's best efforts, he was not diagnosed in time to be treated. Niko was a  Rottweiler,  and from what I understand, I was a lucky girl to have him in my life for such a long spell.  Niko came to live with me when  a coworker smartly realized he was not prepared for the effort and energy of pet ownership - but I believe from Dorn Roshen Kennel. column9: I have recently moved back to my home in Kentucky from NYC.  While in NYC, I adopted a dog from IOHR who is now 3 years old and named Hardy. He was one a litter of 7, actually rescued from KY, which I took as a sign we were meant to be. He is hands down the BEST dog I have ever adopted. He is my constant companion, and the furry love of my life.  I’ve followed the stories of the dogs in the Middle East, especially Cairo, and have always wanted to adopt one from that area and show them what being a dog SHOULD always be about - love, companionship, toys, play, and all the attention they’ll allow :).  My home in Kentucky has plenty of space (4 bedroom,) and is on 300 acres of fields and woods, any dogs paradise. My baby, Hardy, is extremely friendly and definitely could use a playmate, and now that I am out of a tiny NYC apartment, I am ready to open my heart again.

column9: I have been a dog lover my whole life & then a dog owner 1991-2004. I also grew up with our family’s two yellow Labrador retrievers. After graduating University and with an established career, I was the proud Mother of my two beloved American Eskimos. I was heartbroken when they passed away within one year of each other. And still grieve-stricken to this day when my mind wanders to that place in time. For the past couple of years I have been considering the idea of adopting a rescue dog. Now that my daughter is independent, I have been researching the process. When my sister brought home their Chocolate Labrador, Remy, in 2017, I fell in love. Remy & I have formed an unexpected bond…he follows me throughout their house, plops himself at my feet, or plops his big body on top of me when sitting on the floor. I engrossed myself in Remy’s care, training, feeding, housebreaking, & walking…And then I miss him when I leave my sister’s NJ home. During my last visit in August, there was a pivotal moment during which I was getting ready to leave:  Remy is aware I am packing up. He is following me back & forth as I load my SUV. He tries to gently clutch my arm with his mouth while I pet & kiss him good-bye. He barks as I get into my car. He will not leave the driver’s side door. No treats will persuade him. My sister has to pull Remy away from my SUV. Finally in the house, he pries at the slightly open the door. He leaps out & bounds right back to the driver’s side door. He is just sitting there looking up at me, waiting for me come out. I can barely look at him without breaking into tears. Now the whole family is pulling him away from my car. He is tugging back & craning his neck toward me during the entire struggle. Remy is back in the house, but now at the window. He has jumped up & is barking. He is watching me drive away all while following the whole length of the window. That was the pivotal moment…when I realized I am missing a dog in my life. I am ready to take the next step. I have always been financially ready. But now I am prepared both emotionally & physically to take on the responsibility of a rescue dog…as long as it is the right fit for both.

column9: We lost two of our fur babies this past year.  We have always had a full house with four boys and several dogs.  We were just learning to adjust to being empty-nesters, when we sadly and unexpectedly lost 2 of our dogs within 10 months of one another.  One succumbed to lymphoma, and our beloved English Bulldog died of a genetic heart arrhythmia, despite aggressive treatment to stabilize it.  Our home is feeling very quiet these days.   We miss our babies tremendously, and we do mourn them.  We have had dogs our entire lives, and the love and passion we have for them is a love that cannot be duplicated in any other form.  We want to give a new life to a dog that perhaps would not have known love, safety, trust, and a family of his very own, if it had not been for rescue groups such as yours.

They can also provide references regarding my diligence in treating my pets medical condition. Veterinary specialists of Connecticut located in West Hartford, CT.  860-236-3273.  Dr. Welch is a surgeon and repaired Riley and Moonas torn ACL.  She is currently treating Moona for her arthritis. Dr. Uman is an ER vet and treated Daisy for her heart condition until she could get into to see a cardiologist.Dr. Knack is an internal specialist and treated my dog Katie for her cushings disease. Mass Cardiology in Agawam , MA,  Dr. Nancy Morris was the cardiologist that treated Daisy for her heart condition.  Her number is 413-734-1292Pieper Memorial hospital in Middleton, CT treated Riley for his Lymphoma in Dec. 2017-January 2018.  he was under the care of many specialists because of his complicated disease. Katie was under the care for her cancer by Dr. Okeefe.  She is an ocologist at New England Veterinary in Windsor, CT.
column17: If the dog is house broken and is not in danger of harming himself, through chewing,  or getting into anything that could cause him to become sick, he/she will have free run of the house.  If the dog needs to be housebroken, or presents a danger to himself if he/she is unsupervised, then a crate is used when constant supervision isn't possible.  when housebreaking a dog, I don't believe in giving a dog run of a house, rather I keep them in a smaller room with a gate across the doorway so they can be seen, and they are taken out hourly to relieve themselves.  once they go, I allow them to have playtime in the house for a time, then they will be place back in their room, until I bring them out again.  I have never had any problems housebreaking a dog utilizing this housebreaking method.  They catch on very quickly that when they leave their room or crate, the first thing they do is head outside, then that is followed by playtime, and repeated until they are trained.

It has always crosses my mind to bring another pup into my family. I think now is the right time. I have a stable and very comfy job, I work minimal hours only m-fri evenings, and when I am not home, I have a roommate with an exactly opposing schedule who has become family. column20: I adopted a shepherd mix from a city pound when I was in college, in 1988. After college, when I could not take him with me to graduate school, he went to live with my aunt on her horse farm. He was very happy there and settled, so we decided he should stay long-term rather than moving to a city. He died of natural causes at the age of 12. My next dog was a bull terrier who came from a breeder in 1996. I got her together with my ex-husband. When we parted ways, Bella stayed with him because he really needed her emotionally. I adored her, and this was very sad for me, but she was well loved and cared for to the end of her days. I have never put a pet up for adoption or given one to a non-family member.

column9: Since I have been a kid I always been an animal lover. I was fortunate enough to grow up with cats since the age of 5 but even as a toddler dogs excited me and made me so happy. When I was a teen I volunteered at the New Rochelle animal shelter and was responsible for walking green dot and yellow dot dogs as well as taking care and cleaning out all of the animals in the facility. I remember falling in love with this big blue pit mush of a thing but my parents were not ready to have a dog in the house. After about another year I managed to talk my parents into letting me get my own dog but it had to be a small dog, or no dog. I went with a small dog. Her name is Melodi and I have had her since I was 17. I fully trained her myself and even got her registered as a good canine citizen and as a therapy dog. We used to visit hospitals together. As I recently moved back to NY from the UK this time I had to leave her behind. She happily lives with my parents as a 12 year old little character. My dream has always been to have a big dog and as soon as I saw Cruise online my heart just melted. I do lots of running as I am a obstacle course racer and would love to have a training buddy as well.

column2: We currently are actively looking for a place to buy with outdoor space. We would like to adopt a puppy before we move as it's going be a lot easier since we both currently work very close to the apartment (my commute is now 2m40 on foot). On top of a dog walker, we would come back frequently to take the puppy outside and making sure everything goes well. That being said, I'm not sure our current landlord will be thrilled to hear we're getting a second dog. My question is: is there a way you'd skip the landlord reference knowing our current situation is temporary until we find a place and move?I'm more than happy to give you a dozen other references of people who have dogs Chloé (our current dog) has play dates with or people who have volunteered in shelters where you can cross check references.I totally understand this is not an easy request.

column9: We have a 7month old rescue named Turbo (he is a spaniel mix). He was rescued from Puerto Rico and loves to be around other dogs. He is trained and established in our home but seeing how much he loves other dogs makes us want a sister for him. We think it would make his quality of life better day-to-day. He is high energy and loves to play. We go to the dog-park several times a week and walk Turbo at least 2 miles every day....A sister to play with would be the perfect way for him end the day. We are looking for a female dog around the same age and we really love the spaniel demeanor. We live in a spacious apartment but are looking for a medium sized dog around the same size as Turbo so things don't feel cramped (he is going to be 25-30lbs). We need a dog that likes other dogs and children as we are a young couple and hope to have children in the next few years. We also would like a dog that is not afraid of strangers  (Turbo is a little weary of strangers and just getting out of the habit so we would love for a dog that encourages him to relax around people if possible).  We checked off three dogs we are interested in but are also interested in Mattie and Jetta. Obviously we want to be open and find the best fit for us and our buddy Turbo.

column12: Arthur came from a pet store in Greenwich Village (Le Petit Puppy), even though I swore I would never buy a dog from a pet store (and I never will again). We stumbled upon him by accident- he was already 6 months old and the last of his litter. Seeing how alone and sad he was (in a pen all by himself in the middle of the shop surrounded by chaos) broke our hearts. My husband and I decided to take a chance and save him from an uncertain fate in a pet store (they wouldn't tell us what would happen to him if no one bought him). We had terrible anxiety that he would have health or behavioral issues but despite his less then perfect start to life, he is the best dog ever. We still say that getting him that day was the best decision we've ever made.

column9: I have always thought dogs were cute and sweet and have often been exposed to them through close friends, but it was more recently that I seriously thought about having a dog. This happened after a neighbor asked me to watch her 2 dogs for her (a maltipoo and a yorkie). It was my first time ever walking a dog and something about the responsibility of it made me have such a strong affinity for them even though they stayed in her apt (I had keys to walk them and feed them)! Then several months after that, my friend asked me to watch her maltipoo for a week while she traveled for work. This time I had the dog (Sasha) stay in my apartment. It was great experiencing what it would be like especially during the work week since both my husband and I work full time in the city but live in Queens. This probably sold me most on wanting a dog. I am interested in adopting because I know there are so many dogs out there who need a loving home, and I really don’t want to support puppy mills!

column9: I want to adopt because we want to provide the love and attention that a dog (who may have had a hard past) deserves. I grew up around dogs and we are not only so lucky to have these companions in our lives, who love so uncondtionally, but we learn so much from them. I want to be able to do good for a dog and to help give him/her the best (safest, happiest, healthiest, most loving) lives that he/she deserves. Many friends and family members have adopted over the years and I am inspired by the changes they've made in a dog's life.  I want to be able to provide for a dog like that. My adoption process has not been rushed, but rather deliberate. I have waited until I am at a place in my life where I am financially secure and can provide the time a dog needs for the love and care he/she deserves. I believe in the messages and causes that adoption agencies and rescue agencies believe in and I want to give back/contribute.

column9: A house is not a home without a dog. I recently lost my 14 year-old pug (named Pug) unexpectedly. I had him since he was 3 1/2 and it’s left a huge hole in my life and our family’s existence. He’d been diabetic for two years, and those two years revolved around vet visits, insulin shots, testing his glucose, getting pet steps to hop on the couch more easily when he went blind, carrying him up and down the stairs, and home-making dog food every week that wouldn’t upset his stomach. And also of course lots of snuggling, but that’d always been the same since he first came into my life. I have a lot of room in my life and routine to care for a dog of any level of health, needs, or abilities.A little about me: I’m 35 and run a karaoke company out of my apartment. I live with my boyfriend (32), and we have custody of his two nieces, ages 4 and almost 8. They are both gentle, caring little girls who were so good to Pug (never a pulled tail or a stepped-on paw.) We also have a 4 year-old free-flying canary who spends a lot of time flying into the kids’ room and looking out their window to the bird feeders we fill every day. Someone is home nearly all the time, as I work at night and my boyfriend has to be home with the kids. I can guarantee any dog a great home with a lot of attention and care with their own bed and choice of human beds to sleep in.

column9: We love animals and had one rabbit that ran about the house, came when called and was integral to our lives. We sadly lost him to old age this spring.   We fostered two puppies for our local shelter in June and loved it.  I grew up with a lab by my side and while my beloved rabbit, like a dog in some ways, was here we didn't want to complicate things for him with a puppy (not always a good mix).  At this point we look forward to anew family member, which all of our pets have been.  We enjoy being outside, going for walks and hanging out together at home--all of which we love sharing with a dog!  I am lucky to be at home with my work so I can devote a lot of time and attention throughout the day and night to the needs of raising a puppy.
column10: Mellow - Short, daily walks
column11: My animals are up to date on their vaccinations and receive monthly preventatives
column12: A family  nearby with a son in 4-H had a litter of rabbits he was raising--where we got Buttercup many years back.  We have a local pet store that only has fish and few rabbits sometimes--where we got Pansy and Posey at the same time (Posey was one of Pansy's babies). My lab growing up came from a family whose dog had puppies nearby us.  Our rabbits have always been separate so they were not spayed and neutered but I am a firm believer in spaying and neutering dogs and cats and talk with the shelter volunteers about it often.  We wonder what can help in some states to make this problem better.Our lab was spayed, my sister's dogs and cats are spayed and neutered..we all completely are invested in this necessity.As to the other question below, we have taken care with our rabbits--they did not have any vaccinations recommended for them, being completely indoors, I suppose.
